newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany, Malaysia agree more flights, code-sharing.
newsitem.headline: Germany, Malaysia agree more flights, code-sharing.

text.p: Deutsche Lufthansa AG and Malaysian Airline System Bhd will be able to fly code-sharing services between Germany and Malaysia under liberalised air relations between the two countries, the German Transport Ministry said.
Ministry spokesman Franz-Josef Schneiders said increased flights and immediate code-sharing operations have been agreed in negotiations this month between the two countries.
"Traffic rights will be expanded step by step from five weekly flights to nine up to 2001," he told Reuters.
At present, Lufthansa and Malaysia Airlines (MAS) are each permitted five flights a week, although Lufthansa does not use its capacity fully, he explained.
Lufthansa currently flies twice-weekly between Frankfurt and Kuala Lumpur with a Boeing 747 passenger aircraft.
MAS has three services a week to Frankfurt and two a week to Munich with a B747-400 aircraft.
Schneiders said each airline will be allowed a sixth weekly flight from April 1997 and one extra weekly service will be permitted each year from 1999-2001.
"It has also been agreed that code-sharing will be possible between the countries with immediate effect," he added.

Schneiders said this applied to services to both countries, noting that Lufthansa and partner Thai Airways International could thus operate code-share flights between Germany and Malaysia via Bangkok.

MAS has code-sharing deals with several international airlines, including British Midland, Virgin Atlantic, Ansett Australia and Canadian Airlines International. --Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44-171-542-7706 Fax +44-171-542-5017
